Is this offer fine?

Education: B.E. in Information Technology
Years of Experience: 3 years 9 months
Prior Experience: SDE-2 at Zomato
Prev. comp: 36L Fixed + Stocks

Company: Phone Pe
Date of the Offer: May 2022
Title/Level: Software Engineer (SDE-2 level)
Location: Bangalore
Salary: Fixed 48LPA
Signing Bonus: 8L
Retention Bonus: 8L
Stock bonus: $50K worth (Approx. 37L) ESOPS over 4 years, 25% vestment each year, monthly vestments from 2nd year

Total comp (Salary + Joining Bonus + Retention bonus + Stocks) for 1st year: 73.25L
Benefits: Standard benefits
Other details: Negotiated once to get more fixed salary on the basis of having other offers and joining early

## Interview process:

Round 1: Live coding round 
I was given a contact sync problem and had to design my solution around it. The two devs on the interview panel later asked deep questions around syncing issues, timestamps and more. 

Round 2: PS/DS round 
The interviewer told me to focus on showing me the process and that it's not needed to definetely answer the correct algorithm. The questions won't be from geeks or leet code type but will be more descriptive. 

Round 3: Android round
The interviewer asked me deep questions on the work on my resume, we went into depth around dagger and koin, and then to recycler view, glide internals and some coroutines questions. Mostly stayed on my experience and work on my resume. 

Round 4: Hiring manager
It revolved around the question to design a stock watchlist page and the architecture to use - whether MVVM or MVI. I was also asked what if I"m making a new project, will I choose compose or not?

------
Overall process is very good and the panel is knowledgeable.
Final decision: Accepted the offer. 

Rejected the following: 
Navi - https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/2031875/Navi-or-SDE-2-or-Bangalore
Paytm - https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/2031911/Paytm-or-SDE-2-or-Bangalore

Meesho - https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/2031890/Meesho-or-SDE-3-or-Bangalore

## Interview process:

Hi All,

I needed some advice and wanted to have some discussion about company switch. So I thought to indulge with the leetcode fam as they might help.

Benefits: Standard google benefits for India
Other details: 3 coding rounds + 1 system design + 1 behavioral

**Prep strategy**
Nothing special to be honest. For coding, I did a lot of leetcode questions. I used to handle interviews at my previous company, so I know what interviewers look for and what I should not be doing. For example, talking through my thought process, asking questions to clarify if I don't know something, testing my code without waiting for the interviewer to prompt etc.,

For system design, I did a few mocks online and watched a lot of videos. 

For behavioral, because I used to work at FAANG before, I was able to apply some of the things around leadership. I was not asked general questions like how I handle conflicts etc., It was more about what I would do as VP of engineering and things like that. I didn't specifically prepare for these kind of questions either. 

**Interview experience**
Coding questions were all medium level. For one, I had to write over 100 lines of code because I had to write all the APIs for a trie as well as the function to solve the problem using the trie. System design was generic as usual, gathered requirements and went from there. Behavioral was more of a casual conversation.

This was the CTC given without any competing offers. During offer discussion HR gave initial offer for 59 LPA(without stocks), but since my interview feedback was very good he raised it to 65 LPA when I asked if he could bump up the numbers(some back and forth discussion). This was pretty surprising to me as I was expecting a severe lowball because of my current compensation. From my experience, HR had more flexibility in increasing the Joining Bonus and stocks compared to Base.

Looking at recent compensation for Amazon SDE 2, it seems they are paying deserving CTC to candidates no matter how low is their current CTC.

Interview experience: Standard SDE 2 process. 1 phone screen + 1 system design + 2 dedicated coding round + 1 Hiring Manager(Coding involved) + 1 Bar raiser(Coding involved) . And a lot of LPs in all rounds except system design. Prepare a lot for LP questions and also be ready to answer any questions based on the scenarious you put forth. They drilled down deep into all the cases I mentioned for LP.

EDIT:
(1) To help everyone with the same question I had. The answer is yes, Microsoft (I guess other big tech also do similar) adapts the compensation based on your country. So yes, we should avoid asking for US based compensations. I got a pretty good package of benefits comparing with my current position, the level and country where I live.

(2) Thanks for the advice of letting them talk about compensation first. Yep, they did that.

**Amazon SDE1 Offer:**
Base: 25 
JB: 3 for each of next 2 years.
RSUs: 6 RSUs, Standard Amazon Vesting.

Thinking to go with Meesho and if (Maybe?) I don't like it there try Amazon SDE2. Can someone tell me that if I decline amazon I will be blacklisted or something? As you guys would already know there's a colossal pay gap between SDE1 and SDE2 in Amazon. I haven't told Amazon yet about the competing offer, but even if they match Meesho I still would like to go ahead with Meesho as I feel learning would be better and I could try Amazon SDE2 in a year or so, (if not blacklisted LOL). I am specially confident with Amazon because with personal interview experience in Amazon SDE1 and my network's expereinces I feel the overall bar at Amazon is a joke (ofcourse there is always a chance I will be declined, def possible).

**Any Suggestions from you guys are welcome.**

**My Research**: Definitely Meesho's arm Farmiso had 150 lay offs but they weren't techs. (Like OYO had quite a few HR layoff and Netflix recently had layoff again non-tech. But I know can't really compare Meesho with these (ik ik ik) ). Also I did competitive programming in college and even find time to do it know, So confident that can find jobs elsewhere if things go south (Again I know everything I plan can go in the ditch, possible, point taken).

**What I want currently in my career?** : In my current MNC people are awesome, awesome WLB, but learning is saturated I understand Design patterns and stuff but things are already taken care of. I want to make things myself, thats why I am good with aggressive culture. I am ~24 so not really looking from WLB, When I was preparing for JEE in Kota, life was shit, no doubt, but still looking back I feel those guys made me so much stronger and the habits I formed back then continue to help me till today, I am actually looking to have that environment again, Work hard play hard. Seriously need pointers fellas, Also let me know if you guys need more info and Sorry for long post, Many thanks.

**UPDATE**: Just told the Amazon HR that I am taking Meesho will try Amazon SDE2 later if I feel like, she was cool with it, didn't tell me I am blacklisted or anything, Also I must say I had a great experience with Amazon Recruitment all rounds and feedbacks were lightning fast.

**Negotiation Tips:**
Negotiatiging for the right salary is really important. Think of negotitating as another round where you have to use your communication skills to get a good offer, which means you should take some time to prepare for this along with technical and behavioral rounds. Here are some tips to negotiate for a better offer:

1. Never accept the inital offer. There is always room for negotiation even if you do not hold any competing offers.
2. Be polite to your recruiter, they have to bat for you so that you can get a better offer.
2. Do some research on Leetcode to come up with the minimum amount acceptable to you.
3. When recruiter asks for expected salary, never mention the number. Always ask for the budget and use this no come up with your compensation. If they press you too much, ask 15% more than your minimum acceptable amount. You can also just tell them to give the best possible offer for the role.
4. If you are not happy with the numbers presented, do let them know that you are not happy with the offer and mention your achievements and how you would bring value into the organization to ask for more.

Hiring process was of 2 technical rounds + 1 soft skills round + 1 managerial rounds
* First round - It was full technical round. Interviewer checked my code writing skills giving simple real-life problems. Questions were asked from Java, JavaScript and LLD.
* Second round - Full technical round with more focus on problem solving and using data structures and algorithms in our daily life problems. Questions were asked from DBMS too.
* Third round - This round was for checking your english speaking, listening and writing skills.
* Fourth round - This round was maily for salary discussion.

**Recovery of Signing Bonus Clause:** 
* If you work for less than 6 Months at Microsoft after joining, 100% of signing bonus is recovered by Microsoft.
* If you work for less than 12 Months at Microsoft after joining, 75% of signing bonus is recovered by Microsoft.
* If you work for less than 18 Months at Microsoft after joining, 50% of signing bonus is recovered by Microsoft.
* If you work for less than 24 Months at Microsoft after joining, 25% of signing bonus is recovered by Microsoft.

**Recovery of Relocation Clause:**
100% of relocation is recovered by Microsoft if you work at Microsoft for less than 1 year after availing relocation benifits(after relocating to location).

I know this is a good offer as compared to my current salary, but this offer is not at par with the market. This is a non-negotiated salary.

My interviews went well. I have initiated the negotiation over email. Still, any tips/advices would be helpful.

Negotiation Update: 60 days of my notice period are still left (as of 14th July'22). HR said that at this point of time, she doesn't have any solid reason to negotiate and take approvals. If I can convince my current LM to leave me early, she can take it further right now. Second option is that I have to accept the offer letter now and we can revisit the negotiations once my joining date is close (i.e. in August).
I don't have anything in writing, so my plan is to accept the offer letter on the portal and keep giving interviews. If I land a better offer, I will negotiate/reject accordingly and/or will renegotiate in Aug.
I think my HR is helpful (as per all the communications I have had with her) and we can close this in August.

Thanks to all the community members for sharing their advices/experiences. :)

This was the CTC given without any competing offers. During offer discussion HR gave initial offer for 54 LPA, but since my interview feedback was very good he raised it to 65 LPA when I asked if he could bump up the numbers(some back and forth discussion). After a lot of discussion of around ~1.5 hr he agreed to raise it to 80 LPA average package. This was pretty surprising to me as I was expecting a severe lowball because of my current compensation. From my experience, HR had more flexibility in increasing the Joining Bonus and stocks compared to Base.

Looking at recent compensation for Amazon SDE 2, it seems they are paying deserving CTC to candidates no matter how low is their current CTC.

Interview experience: Standard SDE 2 process + 1 extra ML round as team requires good ML knowledge to work on projects. 1 OA + 1 DSA + 1 Hiring Manager(system design HLD) + 1 ML Round(This too was Hiring Manager but with sister team's Manager) + 1 dedicated coding standard round + 1 Bar raiser(LLD) . And a lot of LPs in all rounds. Prepare a lot for LP questions and also be ready to answer any questions based on the scenarious you put forth. They drilled down deep into all the cases I mentioned for LP.

The sign-on bonus is paid in monthly installments for both years. In addition, your offer includes the following benefits:

    -  *Annual leave* of 15 working days in a financial year.
    -   *Sick leave* of 12 calendar days in a financial year.
    -   *Casual leave* of 12 calendar days in a financial year.
    -   *Mandatory and optional holidays* of 10 days in a calendar year.
3. **Medical insurance cover** of INR 5,00,000 (family floater) for you and your dependents (spouse and up to two children).
4. **Accident insurance cover** for up to a maximum of three times annual base pay.
5. **Life insurance cover** for up to a maximum of four times annual base pay.
6. **Annual health check** which helps identify potential issues related to daily nutrition, fitness, and lifestyle habits.
7. **Home internet reimbursement** for up to INR 1,250 per month.
8.   **Meal card** of INR 1,100 per month.

********

**Date of the Offer :** May '22 (On-Campus)
**Company :** Oracle
**Title/Level :** Applications Engineer/Application Developer 2 (IC2)
**Location :** Hyderabad, India. (currently WFH)
**Salary :** ₹ 13,37,761 (Without Including PF & Graduity)
**PF & Graduity :** ₹ 1,01,195
**Relocation :** ₹ 3 Lakhs (Approx)
[Note : Relocation is not Lump Sum. It is handled via a third party & reimbursed against bills and is only for the Employee & his/her Spouse w/ children. NO Parents] 
Need to pay back = 100% of relocation if leaving before 9 months, 50% of relocation if leaving between 9-18 months
**Signing Bonus :** None
**Stock Bonus :** $ 15,000 worth of RSUs vested over 4 years (i.e, 25% annually after each year = $ 3750 = 3 Lakhs) [Will be around 200 RSUs in total across 4 years approx]
**Performance Bonus :** None (Not mentioned in the offer letter or communicated)
**Total Compensation (Salary + PF & Graduity + Stock)** : 13,37,761 + 1,01,195 + 3750*80 = ₹ 17,38,956
**Benefits :** Standard Benefits which includes Employee Medical Insurance w/ Dependets (Spouse & Children only), allowances, etc.

Also Note that Oracle has a slightly more pay range if you are from a IIT/Tier-1 NIT. Have seen other offers with Signing Bonus of 3 Lakhs/6 Lakhs and 600 RSUs over 4 years which is 3 times of this offer.

They tend to add/deduct some components of their salary structure depending on the college for On campus offers. 

Have also seen offers with no stocks and only salary (generally off campus offers or for people switching after a year). So if you are negotiating or getting an off campus offer without these components please do ask them to re-consider their offer. They tend to say that RSUs are not availabe for an Appications Developer/Engineer Role but they are generally low-balling.

Hope this helps.

Here goes..

How are vested RSUs taxed in India? In Oracle, this is how it went for me.\xA0

Say I've got 100 vested in the FY. I received 68 in my account as 31.2% was deducted in the US. Now on my Form 16, I see the INR value of those stocks mentioned in the value of perquisites. Say I had stocks (after 31.2% deduction) worth $10000 valued at INR 800,000. This INR 800,000 is mentioned on Form 16 under the value of perquisites and is taxed again.

So basically I paid 31% tax in the US and then 30% (based on tax slab) in India again.

Is this correct?

* **Company** : Salesforce
* **Role** : Software Engineering Intern
* **Location** : Banglore/Hyderabad
* **Stipend** : 1,25,000 per month
   Along with other standard benefits like Relocation, Medical Cover etc.
* **Duration** : 8 to 10 weeks (May 2023 - July 2023)
* **Education** : B.Tech in EE, NIT (2024 Grad)
* **Prior Experience** : None
* 1 OA, 2 Tech Rounds, 1 HR (all eliminatory in nature)
* **Date of Offer** : 19th July 2022
* It was a pool campus hiring and my college was eligible in it.

  **Tips**

* Salesforce is a highly employee centric company and focuses on its values a lot.
*  Half students get rejected in the HR round so prepare for its HR round well.
* Getting an interview opportunity is tough but apply with a referral off campus for higher chances of getting a call
* Technical Rounds consists of 2 DSA questions and OOPS questions. DSA questions are of easy-medium level but prepare for OOPS thoroughly. Sometime you can be asked to write the implementation of OOPS as well.
* All the best for the internship and placement season 💫💫

My friends had 2 interviews so it depends upon the interviewer that whether he is satisfied or not.

Below is the Compensation structure for Amazon SDE-1 role for people graduating in 2023. This offer was **on Campus**.

Base(Pay)                                = **15,50,000**
Year-1 Signing Bonus             =**9,50,000**
Year-2 Signing Bonus             = **600,000**
Restricted Stock Units(RSU)   = **13,14,713**
Total Comp for 1 Year            = **25,00,000**

**Note:**
1)The bonus is paid monthly, valid for both the years.
2)  The RSU Vesting cycle is 5% after 1st year, 15% after 2nd year, thereafter, 20% every 6 months until fully vested.
3)  Other benefits : Medical Insurance Cover of **5,00,000**, Accident Insurance, Life Insurance, Employee Assistance Program, Annual Health Check, Home Internet Charge Reimbursement, Transporation Allowance and Meal Card.

Interview Experience

For higher level roles at Dropbox, I will say there is a heavy focus on concurrency. Every single question on the onsite was asked to either implement a class which supported some concurrency operation, or write a function where multithreading was necessary.

So, make sure to practice that in the language of your choice. Past that, understand the various threading models, and actually write code (don't just read about them). During the interview, you will be expected to correctly implement these.

In that respect, I believe Dropbox is a fairly difficult company to interview for at an IC3 and above level, because its so different from other roles and requires extra preparation. Hope this helps.

**Education**: B.Tech IT from Tier 3
**Years of Experience**: 1
**Prior Experience**: Reputed product based company
**Date of the Offer**: July 2022
**Company**: Amazon
**Title/Level**: Software Development Engineer (SDE) I
**Location**: Bangalore
**Current Base**: ~INR 17,00,000
**Offered Base**: INR 25,00,000
**First Year Joining Bonus**: INR 5,00,000
**Second Year Joining Bonus**: INR 3,75,000
**Relocation**: N/A
**Stock bonus**: 150 Amazon RSU (5-15-40-40)
**First Year Total** (Base + JB + 5% stock): ~ INR 31,00,000
**CTC** (Base + JB1 + JB2 + 100% stock): ~INR 45,00,000
**Benefits** (In additional to CTC): Standard Amazon Benefits - Meal voucher (INR 1100 per month) + transport allowance (INR 4000 per month) + internet reimbursement (INR 1250 per month).
**Other Offers**: None

**Remarks**:
- Above is negotiated offer, initial offer was ~27,00,000 first year
- My interviews had gone very well, so I was confident in negotiating
- Before offering this salary, I was asked my expected salary over email. I had shared quite high figures there in hopes of pushing the HR to offer me his best. However, the initial offer was lower than what I wanted to settle for.
- The negotiation went on for long and in the end the HR said that they can not do better than 28,00,000. I expressed my dissatifaction and asked them to proceed with the offer if nothing better is possible. However I mentioned that I will "consider" this offer and did not ensure an outright acceptance. I believe this pushed the HR to reconsider and they came back in some time with the above offer.

**Interview Experience**: [Amazon | SDE 1 | Bangalore | July 2022](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/2407702/Amazon-or-SDE-1-or-Bangalore-or-July-2022-or-Offer)

My interview experience was an interesting one:

in the first interview the question was to code a function where the inputs are you coordinates in a city block and a list of locker location in the city, return the closest locker location to the user

the second interview I was asked to design a system and API for a store to upload and manage their inventory on Amazon.com

In the third interview I was asked to design a function that took as inputs, the user object. The function also had access to two API calls GetFriends(User) and GetPurchases(User). The function was supposed to return what the initial user's social circle (two levels deep) was buying from most popular to least popular.

In the final interview I was given a task to design a function that takes a word and list of known words as input, and return the closest known word to what was actually typed.

1. College : Tier 3 college (Electrical engineering), graduated in 2020
2. YOE : 1 yr 6 months ( Infosys/TCS )
3. When started learning DSA? -> December 2021
4. Base : 7,00,000
5. No bonus, no relocation as its near my house.
6. Facilities : Pick and drop by cab
7. Am I Happy? -> Yes I am
8. Happy in 7LPA? -> Yes because for a person who wrote his first line of DSA code in June 2021, its a good start.

Journey : I was pretty much interested in defence. But couldn't clear it due to medical reasons. So as any normal Engineer, I was picked by a service based company. I literally hated to code. So much so that I took Engineering graphics in my 12th. I barely passed C and DS subjects in college. Then after joining my first company, I thought I should do it. But couldn't start in the first 5 months as we had to go through training. So somehow after completing my training, I started on my own and gave around 3 to 4 months. But then in those 3 to 4 months I was allocated a project (tech was ReactJS) and I barely knew the tech. So I started to learn ReactJS first. Now till this time one year passed. I finalised to buy a course from coding blocks. Completed in 6 months and started giving interviews. Initially couldn't get a interview call but then went in Bank of America with a referral and boom, I had gotten my first interview. 

Thankfully, I cleared it and have now taken the offer and eagerly waiting to start my new journey. From a person who hated coding to getting a 7LPA job was dream for me. 

I'd be always remain grateful to leetcode and my first company  which is a service based company as they are the ones who taught me how to code, How to work with ReactJS and for many other teachings. <3 Because of them, I can now say that I can work in IT field.

Interview Experience:
* **Coding/DSA Round** : This was conducted via Karat, was asked medium graph question, and a follow up. Expectation was to write code and run the given test cases. 
* **DSA/LLD Round** : Though this was mentioned as DSA round, some LLD concepts were also discussed regarding coding styles/ garbage collection / OOP concepts. 
* **System Design Round** : This was completely focused on HLD, the interviewer grilled on concepts like databse design, scale, real time performance.
* **Manager Round** : Questions were asked on my past projects, revolving around leadership principles and Atlassian values. 
* **Values Round** : This round had some overlap with the previous round however here more focus was given on how my answers were aligned and reflected Atlassian values.

**Previous TC** : 28L (Base) + 5L (Bonus) + 4LPA RSU's

Hiring was for two profiles SD (Software Developer) and CSD (Commando Software Developer)
CTC: For SD – 7 LPA & 30,000/- PM stipend during the training period.
For CSD – 9 LPA & 35,000/- PM stipend during the training period.

Job Location- Gurgaon

Eligible Branches- B.Tech (CSE/ECE), M.Tech (CSE/ECE)

Eligibility criteria-  60 % in the current degree. Students expecting 60% by the end of last semester may also apply (No backlogs). 

Selection Process:  Aptitude test and technical objective test of 60 minutes followed by a programming test of 150 minutes (All rounds were elimination rounds). The shortlisted candidates then had the virtual interview process. Students were allowed to use any coding language.

My Experience:-
Round 1: Happened on mettle platform. with 60 questions divided into 3 sections, I was able to solve 35 out of 60,(no negative marking though)(questions were of different weightage)

In the Next coding round there were 2 sections, the first section had 3 questions (easy to medium level leetcode) I was able to solve 1 completely and one partially out of them.
In the 2nd section, questions were of medium to hard level leetcode. I was able to solve 1 question partially.

Result: 12 students were selected for the technical interview.
The interview happened the next day. The interviewer asked questions on the problem solved in the coding round and how it could be more optimized, followed by OOPS, DBMS, SQL VS NoSQL, OS, basic linked list, hashing, and collision questions.
The interviewer was very helpful.

Result: 8 students were selected for HR Round.

HR round happened on the same day in the evening.
Round 3: Questions based on family background, what you know about the company, and Job location preference.

Verdict: Finally 4 students were shortlisted (all for SD PRofile )

I have accepted a better offer(after considering various factors) as DRE-II (DevOps & Reliability Engineer) at one of the leading org in Gaming space. Apologies, but won't be able to reveal the offer as of now since I have recently joined. Will update it after few months.

**Journey summary:**
Got rejected from dozens of companies but never backed down. Had to reject few offers that were in last stage(HR/HM rounds) because I got what I wanted. Also messed up in 2 HM/HR rounds initially because of nervousness and got 3 rejections for being "out of budget" after completing all rounds.

There is a lot to achieve and learn but sharing one rule that I follow.
***Devote 2hrs/day apart from office to your personal growth/learnings, no matter what. As they say, 9-5 earns you a livelihood but 5-9 makes you stand out from the crowd. `***

My coding skills are not that strong and I acknowledge it. Have started woking on it in previous few months and will keep grinding.

Edit 1: Thankyou for such a positive response. It means a lot.  
Forever Grateful to the community.

stipend: 35000 pm
period: 6 months
ctc on conversion: 12 - 14 lpa
interview process:
type: campus recruitment
1. shortlist based on resume. 
2. online coding round on hackerearth. 150 minutes, 4 questions on dp, bitwise operations, triplet sum etc.
3. technical round (sde specific): questions on project. interviewer checks if you know nodejs, reactjs and api/database design. most of the work here is in backend with typescript/expressjs/mongodb stack.
4. cultural round: questions on journey so far and your extra curricular/ co curricular achievements. interviewer ensures you don't have higher studies commitments and if converted will atleast stay for 3-4 years.

Company Culture: Super good. WFH policices are great. very friendly and helpful people.

In intership, first six weeks a bootcamp is conducted to familiarize you with the company's tech stack and development policies. This is super important for the next 4 months of your internship.

Given an undirected graph of n nodes in which one node is malware node, return all paths from source to destination which doesn't contain the malware node.

```
  1 - 2 - 3 
 |        | 
(6) - 5 - 4
```
Here, malware node is 6, source is 1 and destination is 5. So, the paths from `2->5` are `2->3->4->5` and `2->1->6->5` but the paths which contains malware node is not valid. Hence, return path `2->3->4->5`.

I received this problem at an on-site interveiw at Google for a Software intern position. We spent about half an hour on this problem. He didn't ask this problem directly but it's similar like CP questions. I think this question would be a LeetCode Medium.

I want to contribute this question, so that it will help someone else because I know a single question related to that company or position matters before the interview. I hope this will help you.

Thank you :)

### Initial Offer

Date of the Offer: September '22
Salary: 30 LPA (Including PF)
Bonus: 3 LPA (0-20 %, assuming 10% average)
Stock bonus: 100,000 USD over 4 years (25% vested each year) ~20.6 LPA / year
Signing Bonus: 8 LPA (6 + 2)
Relocation: 4.2 LPA (1.2 + 3)
Total comp (Salary + Bonus + Stock): ~63.8 LPA Year-1, ~55.6 LPA Year-2, ~53.6 LPA Year-3 onwards.

**Competing offer**: [Atlassian P4](https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/2669576/Atlassian-or-SDE-2-or-Bangalore)

### Revised Offer

Date of the Offer: October '22
Salary: 32 LPA (Including PF)
Bonus: 3.2 LPA (0-20 %, assuming 10% average)
Stock bonus: 140,000 USD over 4 years (25% vested each year) ~28.78 LPA / year
Signing Bonus: 10 LPA (8 + 2)
Relocation: 4.25 LPA (1.25 + 3)
Total comp (Salary + Bonus + Stock): ~76.2 LPA Year-1, ~66 LPA Year-2, ~64 LPA Year-3 onwards.

**Other details**: 
* Despite what I read about Microsoft offers, my experience with them has been very pleasant.
* I did not push them during negotiation, I just informed that I hold another offer with a considerable difference.
* My interviews went well. It could be a factor for the good numbers, but I want to acknowledge how everyone from the recruiter to the Hiring Manager were always helpful and let me consider my options.

Date of the Offer: October 2022
Company: Amazon
Title/Level: SDE2

Joining Bonus: 90K USD year one. 70K USD year two.
Relocation: Standard benefits. Relocated from South America
Stock bonus: 1800 RSUs valued 200K USD (over 4 years)
Benefits: Standard Amazon benefits
TC year one: 270K USD.

Other offers: No.

For those looking for interview experience -
Sructure of interview -

OA.
Phone Screen (LC Medium Generate Parentheses)
Onsite:
1st round: 2 LPs and LLD. (Did 7/10)
2nd Round: 2 LPs System Design. (Did 10/10)
3rd Round: Bar raiser. LC Hard Trie question. (Did 7/10)
4th Round: 2 LPs, Amazon business coding question (Did 5/10).

How I thrived (personal opinion):
- THINK OUTLOUD ALWAYS. There was not a second when I was not talking what I was thinking.
- ACT ON FEEDBACK. Always acted on every little piece of feedback from the interviewer. This shows how coachable you are.
- GREAT SCOPE IN LPs. Prepared my LPs maximizing the Impact of my stories.
- Show technical prowess: Of course I had to solve all of the coding problems, and show that I understood them. But if you don't do great on coding, the three previous items could save your butt.
- GET BREATH AND DEPTH IN SYSTEM DESIGN PREPARATION: Breath because you never know what you could be asked about. Depth because that will make you actually pass the bar of Amazon. Depth is important when discussing Data Bases, Cache, Load Balancer, etc. Some topics I discussed: Consistent Hashing, Vector Clocks, Active-Pasive Failover.

I received 4 offers from my college placements. 

**TCS** :

The exam consisted of aptitude and logical questions. Also a coding section. The coding section was preety much on the easy side. But the apti part was much more tough than the coding.

The interview was very smooth. I was asked some basic oops concept and few other basic java questions. 

**UST GLOBAL : 
**
The interview was very well structured. It consisted of some logical questions, oops concept, hands on coding, psuedocodes, DBMS.

**Capgemeni** :

The interviewer asked basic oops concept.

**ITC : 
**
oops concept  +  coding section in interview. 

Currently, I have not accepted any offer as I am still in my 4th year and I am constantly learning new things and looking for better oppurtunuties.

BACKGROUND
___________________________________________________________
YOE: 1 Year, 3 months
Previous Salary : ~ 7,90,000 INR (Cerner, Bangalore)
College - Tier 2/3
___________________________________________________________
COMPENSATION DETAILS
___________________________________________________________
Title - Apps Dev Programmer - 2
Stack: Java, Angular, TypeScript
Location - Chennai
Total Comp - 17,31,000 INR
Base Pay - 16,38,000 INR
Perks - Cab facility, Medical Insurance (not included in CTC), Higher Education Assistance, Relocation Reimbursement, etc.
Leaves - 30 Personal, 12 Sick, National Holidays. (maternity, paternity, adoption leaves are available)
___________________________________________________________
LIKES
___________________________________________________________
1. Competitive Salary [1.15 Lakhs PM +, after taxes without any investments]
2. Smart people to work with
3. I was able to push my code to prod in the first week. So, clearly they trust you with good chunk of business.
4. No micro management as far as I have seen.
___________________________________________________________
DISLIKES
___________________________________________________________
1. For some employees (not me), DEMAT and Trading accounts need to be disclosed, cannot trade without prior approval which knocks intra trading completely out of life.
2. Not flexible in terms of remote work - Currently following Hybrid culture.
3. They take a lot of time to process anything. Navigating HR folks is a nightmare.

No micro management as far as I have seen.
DISLIKES

For some employees (not me), DEMAT and Trading accounts need to be disclosed, cannot trade without prior approval which knocks intra trading completely out of life.
Not flexible in terms of remote work - Currently following Hybrid culture.
They take a lot of time to process anything. Navigating HR folks is a nightmare.

I'll share the interview experience a little later...but all in all it was super smooth and their process really tests out all the facets of an SWE job. I was lucky enough that I got the written offer just before they announced a hiring freeze...phew!

Verdict: Accepted this offer since it was highest of the ones that I got and WFH is a really sweet benefit.

**Questions 2**: It was an **Medium** Question based on Greedy algorithm.

**Coding Question** : Given Two string, You have to make both the string equal by deleting exactly one character from either of the sting in minimum steps. in one step you can delete one character from either string.

Interview Process:
Round 1: https://leetcode.com/problems/student-attendance-record-ii/
How many possible types of attendence of a student is possible for n days.
Given a student can be present, absent and late on a day.
The student can't be absent for more than 1 day total. And he can't be late for 3 consecutive days.

Input: 
n=1
output:
3
Explaination:
1. L (late)
2. A (absent)
3. P (present)

Input:
n=2
output:
8
AA is not possible as he can't be late for more than 1 day.
Solved using 3 methods
1. Brute force
2. TC : O(n)
3. Gave psuedo solution for O(log n) solution
* Log n solution: Computing for n=2^i
* For example you can compute for n=1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 32 etc
* To compute for n=2^i you need to have information about n=2^(i-1). You need to have how many possible count of n=2^(i-1) ends with 0,1 and 2 consecutive 'L' start and 0,1 and 2 consecutive 'L' end and also about how many of then have 0 and 1 absentes
* So n=2^i can be computed from n=2^(i-1) by using 16 steps((3+3)x2 first 3 comes from  0,1 and 2 consecutive 'L' start next 3 comes from  0,1 and 2 consecutive 'L' end and 2 comes from (0 or 1 absent)) 
* Finally for n=5, you can use computations done for n=4 and n=1
* Similarly for n=10 use computations done for n=8 and n=2. 
* Thus the main step is combining.

Round 2:
The questions asked were
1. https://leetcode.com/problems/count-of-smaller-numbers-after-self/
2. Another question was based on binary search and greedy algorithm

## Rounds:
* Profile Screening Round
* Take Home Assignment
* High Level , Low Level Round
* Low Level and CTO Round

### Profile Screening Round:
Resume , Github and Coding profile was reviewed (had to create a profile on a third party site )

### DSA Round:
Have to create a small project that takes zip codes and returns location name and it's latitide and longitude.
Requirements : 
* 1. Preferable Language - Java or NodeJS (but not a strict constraint)
* 2. Follow best practices for writing modular mode.
* 3. Make sure the code is bug free and thread safe.
* 4. Proper exception handling.
* 5. Your code can be easily integrated with a different provider like positionstack.
* 6. Stub the assumptions you’re making with comments supporting the same.
* 7. All functionality should be tested using unit tests to verify behavior.
* 8. Your code should accept an input file and create an output file


### High Level Round:

Have to design a Leaderboard System (High Level) also have to  write the basic structure of Models, Controllers and Services

### Low Level and CTO Round
* 1. Asked to tell High level design of a Notification system and write low level code.

Requirements:
1. Notification can be for different channels and may contain different type of data and metadata 		
1. Code should be written in such a way that in future the third party notification providers can be changed.

* Questions on projects and tech mentioned in resume.

Round 4: Cultural fit round with the technical lead.

**Other details:** Applied via a job posting on codechef.

Also, can you folks help me in deciding which one to choose for?

PARAMS FOR CHOOSING FOR ME

1. Business Model / Product (Good)
	1. Both are good fintech/mobility, but Lendingkart has some really bad glassdoor reviews, and its looks more like a corporate (political thing), with less autonomy to do things..
	   
2. Good Work + Good Processes (okay)
	1. JVM/Node stack in both places.
	2. Chalo will have more scale compared to LendingKart because of B2C nature.
	   
3. Compensation.
	1.  Both are paying almost equally.
	   
4. Brand Name
5. WLB - Decent in both, learning towards Chalo.

CONCLUSION: Leaning towards Chalo a lot. With better scale, 
and a good tech stack, Chalo looks like a closely-knit team. Bigger impact and more autonomy to do things.

Hello everyone, today I am sharing my first interview experience .
Interview was scheduled of 20th october at 3 pm. I was excited and confident that i will clear my interview.
interviewer joined meeting and we had a formal discussion about my past experience and software development. then Interview started and interviewer gave me some questions and said you have to 45 min to solve these 3 problems , I said okay.

Interview started
1. Write the cieser cipher algorithm in python to encryp the text.
I was able to solve the question then suddenly interviewer asked me to make some changes in the code and I did this But he was not convinced because I was very nervous My english is poor and I didn't do as much as he expected and i failed in the interview.

P.S: if you want to crack a sde job then you must have good communication skills too

Zomato is one of the best company in terms of data science and machine learning in India. 

Role : Data Scientist
Location : Gurugram
Experience : 2 years
College Tier : Tier 3

CTC : 32 LPA
Base Salary : 24 Lakhs
No Performance bonus
Gratuity & PF - 94k
Stocks - 8Lacs with 1 year vesting oeriod
Other Perks & Benefits:
* 	No notice period
* 	Get to meet and work with CXO and top VPs quite often, infact on a day 2 day basis.
* 	You just cant match the scale at which you get to do data science. 
* 	Amazing set of data and problems, you'll be amazed.
* 	Weekly and Monthly townhalls to explain other engineering and business aspects of all their amazing products.

Work Culture:
* One of the worst culture to exist. 
* CEO can say "F*#k off" to any one in company wide meetings like townhalls.
* If a person is senior to you, he/she can throw tantrums at you, demean you, make you feel stupid and abuse you on a day to day basis, doesnt matter which team you belong to. AND you just cant do anything about it, HR is a joke. 
* Some people are really great, understanding, and pleasant to talk to, but you have to be very lucky to be working with such folks. 
* Very adamant about WFO.

When I reached them out again after some time, they informed me that the role is closed and I have not got an offer 🙂.

What is TypeScript?
Microsoft created and maintains TypeScript, an object-oriented programming language.
It's a syntactical superset of JavaScript with the addition of optional static typing.

TypeScript can be used to create JavaScript applications that run on
both the server and the client. The most popular TypeScript programs are also JavaScript
programs.

What is JavaScript?
JavaScript, shortened as JS, is a scripting language that follows the ECMAScript
standard. JavaScript is a just-in-time compiled language with a high level of abstraction
and multi-pattern support.

JavaScript is a programming language that allows users to interact with web pages and is
a necessary component of web applications

Although JavaScript engines were once only found in web browsers, they are now used
on a wide range of servers, most notably via Node.js. JavaScript derivatives include
TypeScript, CoffeeScript, Dart, and Kotlin

Why Use TypeScript?
Typescript is a superset of JavaScript. This means Typescript is a combination of
JavaScript and a few more characteristics. Developers will find it easier to work with
JavaScript due to the language.
Here are some more instances of what TypeScript is used for:
Improve IDE Support:

TypeScript development is a significant improvement over JavaScript development.
Atom, Sublime, Visual Studio Code, and WebStorm are just a few of the JavaScript
IDEs that offer excellent support for both TypeScript and JavaScript.
Interoperability:

TypeScript is strongly linked to JavaScript. As a result, it has high interoperability
capabilities, although it requires some additional work to work with JS libraries in
TypeScript.
Static Typing:

JavaScript is tightly typed, so it doesn't know what kind of variable it's dealing with
until it's practically created at runtime. JavaScript now has type support due to
TypeScript.
Strict Null Examination:

In JavaScript software programming, errors, like cannot to read property 'x' of
undefined, are common. Since a variable that is unknown to the TypeScript compiler
cannot be used, you can avoid most of these errors.
Supports New ECMAScript:
-TypeScript can trans-pile unique ECMAScript criteria to ECMAScript objectives of
your choice. As a result, you can use lambda, modules, functions, the spread
operator, de-structuring, and classes, which are all features of ES2015 and beyond.

Type Inference:

The use of type inference in TypeScript makes typing easier and less confusing. Even
if you don't use the interface, TypeScript can help you avoid mistakes that could
cause runtime issues.
Why Use JavaScript?
JavaScript is in high demand these days, as it is supported by the majority of browsers
and web-based applications. In addition to the web, it's utilized in servers, applications,
and embedded hardware controllers.
The following are some basic reasons why designing a JavaScript application is
preferable:
Foundational Language :

The event-driven software design style organizes the movement of your code by
system events or user events, and JavaScript supports it.
Fun and Interactive Language :

You'll have immediate access to a complete user interface. JavaScript has a
graphical user interface that is both entertaining and simple to use. Early in the
learning process, you can construct browser-based scripts to create interactive
projects.
Learning Support :

Each browser has to source code viewing features that allow you to learn from the
live coding of others. In addition, JavaScript has the largest and most dynamic
library code repository in the ecosystem. Individuals in the JavaScript community
are extremely helpful and active in sharing and repurposing one another's code.
Low Requirements to Start :

Browsers use a programming language called JavaScript. It's a lot simpler to
understand, and you can get started right away. Unlike other languages, JavaScript
does not require you to install a large number of programs before you can begin
using it.
Rich Interfaces :

To provide a rich interface to your website users, you can use JavaScript to include
features like sliders and drag-and-drop components.
Superior Debugging Tools :

The web browser has a collaborative JavaScript interpreter that allows you to
explore and receive immediate feedback, allowing you to learn more quickly.
** Conclusion:

After reviewing all of the information presented in this article, we can conclude that both
languages have advantages and disadvantages.

TypeScript is designed for developers who desire to write understandable, well-
organized code. We're not even going to mention what TypeScript has to provide, such as
live-bug checking and static typing.

Although JavaScript is not a complete programming language, it can be used in
combination with HTML to improve web page quality. You'll also find a lot of seasoned
engineers who know how to code in JavaScript.

Blockchain technology has become one of the most promising and rapidly growing fields in the tech industry. With the increasing demand for blockchain developers, learning how to develop decentralized applications (dApps) and smart contracts has become a valuable skill.

Here are some steps you can follow to learn blockchain development:

Familiarize yourself with the basics: Start by understanding the fundamentals of blockchain technology, including its history, architecture, and the various use cases for which it can be applied. Read whitepapers and articles, watch videos and webinars, and take online courses to get a solid foundation in the basics of blockchain.

Choose a blockchain platform: There are several blockchain platforms available, including Ethereum, EOS, and Hyperledger, among others. Choose a platform that aligns with your goals and interests and dive deeper into its documentation, tutorials, and forums.

Learn a programming language: Most blockchain platforms use a specific programming language, such as Solidity for Ethereum, Web Assembly for EOS, and Chaincode for Hyperledger. Familiarize yourself with the syntax and basic concepts of the language and practice writing simple scripts.

Build projects: Start small and build simple dApps and smart contracts. This will give you hands-on experience with the technology and help you understand how it works. As you progress, tackle more complex projects and challenges.

Join a community: Joining a community of like-minded individuals who are interested in blockchain development will provide you with a supportive network of peers, mentors, and resources. Participate in forums, attend meetups and events, and contribute to open source projects.

Stay up to date: Blockchain technology is constantly evolving, and it's important to stay up to date with the latest developments, trends, and best practices. Read industry publications, follow influencers and experts on social media, and participate in online courses and workshops.

Learning blockchain development can be challenging, but it can also be a rewarding and fulfilling experience. With dedication, hard work, and the right resources, you can become a skilled blockchain developer and make a positive impact on the world.

A horror story with Stanza Living


no benefits whatsoever

They have fired already 50% of Tech and Product Team  


let's start from the beginning 

Strictly work from office with strict timing from 9:30 AM 

every after two hours they will ask if is it done. is it done?

you are supposed to be in the office upto 8-9 PM on normal days and 10-11 Pm on release week and available anytime 


they can fire anyone anytime if you ever disagree with their decisions


they define the expected timeline of the feature not the developers

they just give orders like I want this feature  by tomorrow (sometime by today EOD)

I think its good to be unemployed rather than working here

very toxic work culture just one good thing every developer is willing to help each other 

just ask any developer either who left or currently working ,they will tell you their horror story

every day i eat medicine for headache before going to sleep

Well I was the part of the lay - off from my previous firm. I felt, because the market was so unpredictable it was good to join as soon as possible. I got offer from Toshiba India. I was expecting fixed as 25 Lakhs, but was asked for negotiation in HR round. My previous eaning was 18.5 lakh as fixed and approximately 2-3 lakhs bonus in a year ~10% hike, plus stock of 1-2 lakh in a year. 

I had no intention to negotiate but was not in the condition for taking risk, so I agreed on 22 lakhs as fixed. But it was quite disspointing seeing they offered me 22 lakhs as total CTC where 20.3 is fixed rest is bonus also because it is a Japanese company it would not be giving any stock, and the joining is immediate (next day). 

I accepted the offer letter feeling graditute, ***something is better than nothing***

Please refrain from giving interviews of such companies who give false hopes and waste candidate's time.

**Lesson**:  Be very cautious while taking on campus placements in MNCs.

* **Education:** B.Tech in Information Technology from a Tier-2 College
* **Years of Experience:** 6
* **Prior Experience:** Top MNCs in the Finance, e-Commerce and Software sectors
* **Date of the Offer:** July 2022
* **Company:** Quizizz
* **Title/Level:** Software Engineer (L5)
* **Location:** Bangalore
* **Salary:** 80 Lakhs
* **Signing Bonus:** 2 Lakhs
* **Bonus:** 5 Lakhs (Retention Bonus on completion of 1 Year)
* **Stock bonus:** 24 Lakhs (vested over 4 years, they refuse to tell the exact FMV of an ESOP unit but you can run your own calculations based on the number of allocated ESOP units and the quoted amount and see that it is approx. $10)
* **Relocation:** Flight tickets to Bangalore for the employee (they do not provide tickets for any of your family members that might be relocating with you), Brokerage amount for the flat that you finalize and expenses for moving your furniture and belongings to Bangalore.
* **Total Comp (Salary + Bonus + Stock):** 93 Lakhs (First Year), 86 Lakhs (Second Year onwards)
* **Benefits:** Wellness Reimbursement (INR 20,000/Year)
* **Other details:** 
	* After the recent layoffs that have been happening in 2023, ***they have started laying off their existing employees that were on the higher side of the compensation spectrum and hiring their replacements at half of what they were offering earlier*** taking advantage of the sudden increase of people in the talent pool in the industry and the desperation for jobs among candidates. Unfortunately, I was also affected as a result of this and let go around new year 2022-23 (after just 4 months).
	* The company is a great place to work for as long as you are willing to accept a nominal hike or get somewhat lowballed. If you manage to negotaite a "higher salary", you will always be on the risk of being let go as soon as they find a more "econimical" replacement for you.
	* The company is doing quite well and making good profits and is self sustained as well with a decent runway. Moreover, it hardly has 150 employees. So, it is very strange and sad to see the company taking such steps to save a few lakhs and tainting the entire Indian startup ecosystem in the process.

✅ Step 1: Read and understand the problem statement

- Take the time to read it carefully and make sure you understand what the problem is asking for.
- Identify the input and output, constraints, and any special requirements.

Resources:
Online coding forums and communities such as Stack Overflow, Reddit, and Quora.

Tools:
Code editors such as Visual Studio Code or Atom for writing and editing code.

Ex: Let's consider an example where we need to write a program to find the longest common prefix in an array of strings.


✅ Step 2: Analyze the problem and break it down

- Try to Break it down into smaller, more manageable parts.
- Identify the sub-problems, inputs, and outputs, and make a plan to solve each one individually.

Ex: We can break down the problem into finding the common prefix between two strings and then recursively finding the common prefix of all strings in the array.

✅ Step 3: Choose the right data structure and algorithm

- Based on the problem statement and the sub-problems identified in the previous step, select the appropriate data structure and algorithm to solve each sub-problem.
- Use your knowledge of data structures and algorithms to choose the most efficient one.

Resources:
LeetCode, HackerRank, and Codeforces to practice and improve your skills.

Ex: In the longest common prefix example, we can use a Trie to store the prefixes of all strings in the array and find the longest common prefix by traversing the Trie.

✅ Step 4: Implement the solution

- Write the code for each sub-problem, test it, and make sure it works as expected.
- Once you have implemented the solution for all sub-problems, combine them to get the final solution for the problem statement.

Tools:
Code editors such as VSCode or Sublime Text

Ex: In the longest common prefix example, we can implement the solution using Python and the Trie data structure.

✅ Step 5: Test and optimize the solution

- The final step is to test and optimize the solution.
- Test the solution with different inputs and edge cases to make sure it works for all scenarios.
- Identify any performance issues and optimize the solution if needed.

Resources:
Testing frameworks such as JUnit or NUnit to automate testing
Profiling tools such as VisualVM or Xcode Instruments to identify performance bottlenecks.

Tools:
Debuggers such as PyCharm or Visual Studio Code for identifying and fixing.

A bit about the process:
=> **OA** had 2 questions to be solve in 1.5 hours (I was able to solve one, and partial testcases ran on the other question)
=> **Interview** had 3 rounds (2 technical + 1HR). 
Technical rounds were based on some DSA questions (I was lucky to get easy ones, but my friends were asked standard hard questions, like Trapping Rain water, and KMP).
Basic questions on OOPS and OS were asked. My projects were discussed in detail. Even though they had come for SDE profile, they seemed very interested in one of my ML projects, and surprisingly asked ML questions in great depth. The HR round was more like a general interaction.

Hi Everyone,

Lots of candidates are fascicated towards Browserstack Compensation and Permanent WFH Policy But they should know some real insight of the company.

My intention is not to disparage Browserstack, but rather to provide an accurate portrayal of the company and its employees.

Let's see some Pros ✅

No Doubt, All the members of software developers are amazing and really helpful.
In your role, you'll be exposed to a diverse range of technologies and various programming languages, which will provide you with a valuable opportunity to expand your skillset.
Working with Browserstack will provide you with a valuable opportunity to gain experience in managing a startup, leading teams, and overseeing the software development processes.
Let's see cons 😈

You are going to forget about what's a good work life balance because there no such concept in reality but surely a good WLB is present only on papers or offer Letters.
They will treat you like a nothing. you are only resources for them. They will going to utilise you until you are going to say - "there's too much of Task in the plate"
The company often uses the term "responsibility" as an excuse to assign multiple tasks with tight deadlines. Even if you work hard from morning till late at night, there's always a possibility of some tasks being left unfinished. In such cases, the company will view you as an irresponsible person, regardless of the effort you put in.
The company did not explicitly declare that they were laying off employees. Instead, they are using a program called "PEP" (Performance Enhancement Plan) to justify the termination of many software developers who have received low performance ratings.
The most concerning aspect of their system is that they did not offer any severance package to the affected employees. Furthermore, they even took back the work-from-home reimbursement amount from some employees, and if an employee mistakenly asked for the money back, the company ignored their requests and stopped communicating with them altogether. It appears that the company does not value these employees anymore.
There Feedback system is worst than you think. you will Laugh at some point is this Really a point to discuss. In short if they decided to give you a poor Rating then No body can stop them
The company's main focus seems to be taking advantage of the fact that their employees are working from home permanently. According to them, since employees are at home, they have no other distractions or commitments, so they try to push for maximum output under the mask of responsibility and quarterly ratings.
The company does not believe in rewarding or showing appreciation for minor accomplishments or tasks, unless you have created an extraordinary system or exceeded their expectations in some way.
The ideology they used was Use and Throw

There's no need to be afraid of the current market situation. While it's true that there's a recession happening, it's also a fact that there are many job openings available. Preparing for interviews is a very different game than working for an organization. Those who have appeared for interviews must be knowing about it. Believe me, if you start interviewing for multiple job openings, you will gain a lot of valuable experience throughout the process. Have confidence in yourself, even in the current situation, and you will surely find a job placement soon.

This whole experience was so bad for me and lots of my friends and I wanted to share this with the community so that they decide well before joining any company.
Thank you for reading this long piece of text.

I'm Writing this review after working for 2 year
On the positive side, the company has a great team of employees who are dedicated and hardworking. The company culture is also very welcoming and inclusive, with frequent team-building events and opportunities for collaboration.

However, I have noticed that there are some issues with work-life balance at the company. There have been times when I have been asked to work long hours and in night without adequate compensation or recognition. This has led to some burnout and stress among employees.

Additionally, there could be more growth opportunities and policies in place to support employees' professional development. While there are some training programs available, they are not always well-organized or tailored to individual needs.

This created a stressful and unsustainable work environment, which ultimately led to high levels of employee burnout and turnover.

There have been some concerns raised about micromanagement by certain managers. This can be frustrating and demotivating for employees who would like more autonomy in their work.

Overall, while there were some positive aspects to working at FOX, the company's work-life balance, growth opportunities, and micromanagement policies were significant areas of concern. I would recommend that the company take a more proactive approach to address these issues to better support their employees and improve the overall work environment.

# How I got job on freelance
One day, I said to myself, that I wanna do something, I wanna work, but not full-day, cause I am stydying at school rn, so I decided to sign up on freelance and find job in there. I spent like 2 hours finding and responding to tasks, then one person wrote me back, and said that he has a job for me. I should wrote frontend and API of kinda small mobile application on Flutter. So I did. Than that person gave me bigger project with double salary. Same thing, flutter, frontend, API.  

Education: 10 years at school
Years of Experience: 0
Prior Experience: Learned Flutter from 2020, won some contests(such as National Technological Olympiad)
Date of the Offer: April 2022
Company: Freelance
Title/Level: Frontend developer
Location: Remote
Salary: 625$ per one project and 1250$ per second
Benefits: can code less than 20 hours per week
Other details: mean salary in my country is near 700$ per month if you work full day, so and I got like double for just only frontend of 2 simple mobile applilcations on Flutter, I should write frontend + API, so that's quite good, and fact that I am still studying in school means that from this moment I receive years of experience which will help me to find a good job in the future

## So what I wanna say
Is that if you have a lot of free time and you love coding and ready to do some tasks which will require some time, go on and find a job, freelance is a good place to do it, you should try to find some tasks that you want to do and respond to them, there is always a chance that employer will choose you, I guess **in my case** reason why I was chosen is that employer wanted projects to be finished as fast as possible, and I have 100+ WPM typing speed, I wrote it in my resume, and got a job. Your reason may be different, but you **should** write in resume about **any** your good qualities. Good luck with finding a job

Need some advice on a compensation related issue. 

I work for a startup as a Lead.
My org has recently hired a lot of new candidates from quite a few reputed companies.
And I recently got to know, from other colleagues, that these new hires are being paid more than me.

The thing which makes me feel like shit is that I am an 8YOE candidate and they have around 5-6YOE.
If that is not enough, look below:

1. I definitely *definitely* add more value than these new hires whether it be in terms of tech design, PR reviews, confusion resolution etc.
2. I handle multiple teams and they are working as part of 1 team.
3. I delivered 2 high pressure projects recently. 
4. I am leading couple of 2 new projects where nobody has a fucking clue about what needs to be done and they have nothing under their belt so far.
 
I feel extremely *extremely* shitty when I hear that I am being paid less than them whereas I contribute more to the org in any way you look at it. 
When they come to me for PR reviews and technical advice, I feel even more shittier about the fact that I being the reviewer get paid less than the reviewee.

This is eating me up on a daily basis. My mind automatically goes to that unfairness if I sit idly for more than 10 minutes.

Can anybody advice me on what can I do in this situation.

Was thinking long and hard about this and couldnt come up with a counterexample, so posting this here. 

* Indian Startups are NOT doing anything INNOVATIVE. It the same thing that most of them are doing just packaging them in different containers. Lets take the example of some of the biggest startups in India Swiggy, Zomato, BigBasket, Flipkart, Myntra etc(i know some are bigger than startups and some have been acquired), they all are doing the same thing. Some of them are selling clothes, some grocery, some appliances, some food. Each year a new startup comes that promises to deliver grocery in 5 mins less than the competitor. IMO all these startups are bound to fail at some point. Lets take the case study of Swiggy, Zomato. They both are eating from the same pie and the pie aint getting any larger. Its not like you will start consuming breakfast twice because of these companies. so as more companies start adding to this pie, the profit of Swiggy, Zomato will decrease(its bound to happen). What can be done? Open their business in new cities? Oh but hardly the restarurant infrastructure is there in smaller cities. So they need to diversify their business at some point to selling something other than food.
* Most of the engineers working in these companies are also doing the same thing, maintaining Kafka queues, wriitng springboot to create a microservice that fetches some things from some queue and process it, or look at the data spit out of these services etc. The only new thing that they have to encounter is during these Big Billion Sales, where need to do the usual things at scale. But other than that what are they learning?

Please post your opinions. Would really love to hear everyones thoughts on this. Hope I am wrong.

As a Full-Time expected time is 6-8 hours.

For Demo classes you'll get 50 INR per Class, for Paid class you'll get 250 INR per class.

**Education**: Currently in 3rd year B.Tech Program at one of the old IITs
**Prior Experience**: Global Alpha Researcher at Trexquant
**Company**: Trexquant
**Title/Level**: Quantitative Research Intern
**Location**: Gurugram, India
**Stipend**: INR 3,20,000(~$4000) per month
**Duration** : 8 Weeks (2 Months) Summer Internhsip
**Other Offers** : I had an offer to join an HFT based out of Gurugram for a Tech Role, but Stipend was lesser than what's offered here. 

I have been working at Trexquant as a Global Alpha Researcher and like the work and the inclusive culture of the firm, so I decided to intern here this summer. I was offered the Intern role based on my performance in the Global Alpha Researcher(GAR) Role. The Internship role and the GAR role are very similar wrt to the the work/projects assigned and also compensation wise. I have even seen my fellow GARs make more than the above mentioned stipend, since there is a huge performance based component. The major difference is that the GAR role is remote and one can work from anywhere, whereas for the Internship we need to be present in the firm's Office in Cybercity Gurugram.

**Reasons for Accepting the Offer** : 
1. As GARs we get complete ownership of the work we do, and firm recogonises the efforts and rewards the top performers with monetary awards regularly. 

2. The mentorship and feedback provided by the senior management is a big upside of working here. The upper management(even the CEO) is very easily approachable to discuss innovative ideas and trade them in live markets. 

3. The stipend I feel is at par with the top HFTs and is more than what peers like Worldquant offer to Summer Interns.

Experience: 4.5+ years
Education: Tier2 , 2018 passout , ECE graduate
Current Compensation: 33L Base + ESOPs as SDE2 Backend
Current Org: B2B SaaS startup , good company but limits on compensation
Expectations before switch - 45+ Base

Decided to switch in January after bad appraisals , preapared DSA for 10 days and HLD-LLD for 10 days.
My current work had a good exposure of HLD and LLD , so didn't have to put exhaustive efforts into preaparing for design rounds. 
Started applying in Feb and this is where fun began , applied to mroe than 500 companies but was getting very few responses , those who were responding were ghosting after first round or trying to lowball

First Phase - Interviewed at Fampay ([experience](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3609350/Fampay-Feb-2023)), BharatPe , BigBasket , Sensibull ([experience](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3609365/Sensibull-Feb-2023)), Clarisights ([experience](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3609372/Clarisights-Feb-2023)), Anakin  , Enterpret in the first Phase .
Few of them rejected , few of them ghosted. **Cleared 2 companies - Fampay and Anakin but none of them was offering remotely close to my expectations.**

Seconda Phase - Approached by a few more companies in my second phase but very few offering 40+ base , did not take interviews at companies which were not ready for 40+. Interviewed at Atlan([experience](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3609429/Atlan-March-2023)) , Motive ([experience](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3609403/Motive-March-2023)) , TekionCorp ([experience](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3609449/TekionCorp-March-2023)) and a UK based very early stage startup.
Cracked the UK based startup , was a very good opportunity.
**First offer - 43 Base + 2 Variable + relatively large ESOPs as it was early stage startup**
Resigned with notice period 45 days

Phase 3 - Aggresively started wih Phase3 
PhonePe ([experience](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3609494/Phonepe-April-2023)) , Sharechat([experience](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/3609519/ShareChat-April-2023)) , Coinbase , Wayfair , Twillio , LevelAI and a mid size startup
was approached by multiple other companies but declined many of them because either they weren't that good or compensation wasn't good enough

**Second offer - 48 Base + 2 Variable + ESOPs from another mid size startup**
**Phonepe rejected after First salary discussion saying not good enough LLD skills(no feedback) , but anyways they weren't offering above 45 Base**
**Sharechat Offer - 40 Base + 4 Variable + 4 Joining Bonus  . Had told sharechat that my expectations are 50+ , still wasted my time interviewing here
Couldn't clear coinbase , but they would've offered 70L+ (~43 base + RSUs) , only company giving more than my final offer in hand but I couldn't crack it :(**

***`Joined that mid sized startup with final offer - 48 base + 2 variable + ESOPs , tried to stretch it further but there wasn't any other offer backing it`***

```
Lessons Learned - 
Negotiate Hard , Have multiple offers , Don't get lowballed (Very Important as many companies are trying to leverage market situation) .
Instead of getting overwhelmed , focus on One step , One interview , One Company at a time .Learn from each interview and Grind for the next one.  
Your 2-3 months of efforts would make a huge difference .
Frankly a very few careers in the world offer such ROI on your efforts So be grateful for that and GRIND.
```

offline OA
**Process date : mid sept 2022**
 4 questions were asked 1 hour 30 minutes where given
1 easy 2 medium 1 hard
easy was based on set count (all test cases passed)
1st medium was to check if a point is inside the triangle or not (49/50 test cases passed)
another medium question is present on gfg archive you can check there (all test cases passed)
1 hard it was kinda digit dp but I was not sure if I will be able to code it properly so I coded knapsack and I was able to pass it partially (12/15 test cases passed)

There was a set of questions my friends got different questions
so I was shortlisted for Personal Interview Rounds  total of 30 students were shortlisted from my clg so there were a total of 3 rounds 2 technical and 1 hr

All the rounds where offline company visited the clg
Round 1 ->
So he went through my resume and OA test score. As my testscore was good so he said he will not ask many coding questions. So he started asking questions based on projects and my 2 internships. So I have done projects in web development. He asked REST API, and MVC how rest API sends the request to the server. He asked me to code some functionalities that I have made in my internship and projects. He asked about dockers and Jenkins as I have worked on them as one of my interns. So basically he asked each and every word mentioned on my resume.
So the result came around 17 people cleared 1st round and I was one of them.

Round 2->
So In this round as well projects-related stuff was asked and internship-related stuff. But he focussed more on databases and routes. he asked about MongoDB schema, queries, oops-related concepts, DBMS, and a bit of os thread-related stuff. he asked me to code some javascript functionalities that I have made in one of my intern on paper. then he started asking about DBMS theory and SQL queries were also asked. Overall the round went well. I was able to answer almost everything. So the result came for me in 15 minutes. Round 2 and Round 3 were going on parallelly from here on. So I got selected for 3rd round

Round3->
It was hr round he asked general questions from me. Easy puzzles were also asked in this round. General discussion about my future goals. As I'm from a non-circuital branch so he asked me why I want to switch to the software field that's it. Then I asked a few questions from him round ended in 30 minutes ig

So after a long wait of around 3 hours as PI's were going on for others. All the interviewees came into the common sitting hall to announce the results. I was a bit nervous as I was rejected before in oracle after the hr round. But this time the case was different they announced my name and I was 1 of the 12 students selected from clg.

Thank you for reading hope you find it useful. If you have any doubts you can drop a comment.

I have 2 years of experience, been applying to companies for like 6 months now. I got like 4-5 calls after applying to almost 750+ companies. When will this terrible market situation improve? Is there any hope for us left? 

Most people are telling like apply as much as possible, give as many interviews as you can, you'll definitely get selected, apply to 100-200, you'll get atleast 5, and bla bla bla. 
My question is that, if we can't even get any calls from recruiters, how in the world will we be able to give "as many interviews as we can"?

Going forward, will this situation ever improve? Every job opening on Linkedin gets atleast 1000 applications within a few minutes. At this rate, what I feel is that even when the economic conditions get better, there will be so many of applicants out there who are applying that most people would never get any call.

And the people who are most affected are in the 0-3 years experience range. Most companies who have openings are hiring like Lead Engineers, Principal Engineers, Tech Leads etc with 6-8+ years of experience. I wonder, if all these companies are needing so much of people with 8 years experience, what will the lesser experienced people do? Whom are all these team leads leading if they don't even need any junior level people? After few years, how will companies be able to get experienced people if freshers from colleges and people with 1-2 years don't get hired now and get proper experience?

This is just a rant which will probably lead to nowhere. If you have read this far and have any suggestions/anything on your mind, feel free to comment and share your thoughts.
